Award.AwardTitle: Identifying Selection Pressures on Viral Genomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will develop sophisticated likelihood-based statistical models of molecular evolution to infer and investigate evolutionary patterns from alignments of coding sequences. In their most general form, the models allow the pattern of substitution to vary across the phylogenetic tree, across sites in the alignment, and to depend on the residues involved. The models also accommodate the effect of recombination by permitting phylogenetic histories to change between regions of an alignment. These evolutionary patterns will be derived from the data, rather than from a priori assumptions, through the innovative use of genetic algorithms to search for good-fitting models. The investigators will assess convergence and coverage properties of different algorithms. As there may be many models with similar fits to the data, inference based upon the best fitting model will be compared with those obtained by a weighted average over a sample of models. The unparalleled level of biological realism and statistical sophistication accommodated by our models will permit the research team to perform rapid and accurate high-resolution comparative studies of large collections of genes. New techniques will help bridge the emerging gap between meta-genomic analyses made possible by modern sequencing techniques and existing evolutionary analysis techniques developed in the single-gene era. These models will be developed and validated using a variety of viral datasets, focusing on the three pathogens - human immunodeficienty virus type 1, influenza A virus and hepatitis C virus - for which there is a wealth of sequence data.

Over time, evolutionary processes, such as natural selection, mold every gene into a unique mosaic of sites evolving rapidly and resisting change - an "evolutionary fingerprint" of the gene. Much like ordinary fingerprints, they contain a wealth of information, identifying similarities and idiosyncrasies of individual genes. However, current techniques can only identify coarse evolutionary patterns, and are not well suited to the analysis of extermely large genomic datasets which are being generated at an ever-increasing rate. This project will bring unparalleled resolution to gene fingerprinting using sophisticated mathematical and statistical models and high-performance computing. The project will generate new state-of-the-art software tools for the use of the scientific community. The investigators will apply new techniques to viral pathogens that have had a serious impact on global health, including HIV, Influenza A virus and Hepatitis C virus, leading to a significant improvement in our understanding of viral evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic Algorithm (GA) -driven substitution model selection

The main purpose of the grant was to develop and validate a GA-based information theoretic procedure for inferring which evolutionary models, out of a combinatorial large number of possibilities, are credible for alignments of protein-coding genes and assist in their interpretation (sections 3.3.1,3.3.2 and 4.2 in the original proposal). We are happy to report  that we have successfully completed this aspect of the proposal.

Importantly, by using a properly stringent model selection criterion (modified BIC, validated by extensive simulations), we do not overfit the data (in fact the method 1% of overfitting), have excellent power (approaching 100%) to infer the correct model (converg- ing on the single correct model out of > 10200 total quickly for large enough alignments).

 In the process of validating the GA, we have found and corrected a previously-unrecognized bias in character frequency estimator which is in ubiquitous use in evolutionary literature, with well in excess of 1000 papers using models with this estimator); in some cases this bias can lead to serious inferential errors. We submitted a note describing the findings to PLoS ONE.

Evolutionary Fingerprinting of Genes

We have developed and published a novel methodology; which enables the computation of “evolutionary distances” between any two coding sequence alignments in order to quantify and make use of the selective forces acting on viral (and other) genes and downstream applications (section 2.2, 4.3 and 4.4 of the original proposal). This study has been made possible by the methodological advances and computing power funded directly or in part by this proposal. The results were published in Molecular Biology and Evolution [6] and the results are summarized in the following abstract. The evolutionary selection distance metric developed here forms the basis of the conceptually novel ability to formally compare (cluster, find outliers, make predictions about function by evolutionary homology) of non- homologous genes to which none of the standard phylogenetic approaches apply.

GA-based recombination detection

The paper describing the best-in-class phylogenetic approach to detecting recombination in HIV-1 (and other) sequences has been published in PLoS Computational Biology, and its implementation online (www.datamonkey.org) has processed over 200, 000 sequences since its release. A version of this algorithm has become a part of several genotype and phenotype assays developed and performed by Monogram Biosciences.

 

 Project-supported collaborations

  1. We applied evolutionary fingerprinting to characterize selective forces acting on poly- merase and capsid genes of norovirus GII.4.
  2. We developed a variety of computational techniques to use next generation sequencing data for metagenomic analyses and implemented the tools in Galaxy – an NSF- supported (NSF grant DBI 0543285) software system for reproducible research. Such analyses are increasingly important as deep sequencing becomes cheaper and more ubiquitous.

We used codon evolutionary models to characterize viral evolution during and fol- lowing sexual transmission of HIV-1.

Public web services

Project funds have enabled us to increase the power of our computing cluster by a factor of 8; in addition to supporting internal computational tasks, the cluster powers a popular datamonkey.org evolutionary analysis server [4], which processes about 130 CPU intensive (an average of 35 CPU/hours) jobs per day. Drs Pond and Delport have implemented Datamonkey modules for codon model selection, evolutionary fingerprinting, SCUEAL and toggling natural selection.
